attributes.title: Independent Councils and Territorial Redistribution: Survey Evidence from Canada

q1.value: Independent Councils and Territorial Redistribution: Survey Evidence from Canada

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Every year, the Canadian federal government provides equalization payments to provinces with below-average capacity to raise revenues. The purpose of these transfers is to ensure all Canadians enjoy similar levels of services at similar levels of taxation. But the distribution of transfers is not always fair or efficient. One possible way to address this problem – and one that appears to work well in Australia – is to establish an independent fiscal council capable of assessing the performance of Canada’s federal-provincial transfers. This body could work as a “watchdog,” alerting voters to unfair and inefficient transfer arrangements. But the success of a council depends on its ability to convince voters to adhere to national norms of fairness, even when those norms mean less money for their provinces. Is a council capable of such influence? This research will examine this question with a survey experiment in Quebec. We will present control and treatment groups with a description of the equalization program and a proposal to reform it. The proposed reform would not affect Quebec’s equalization payments. But it does propose higher payments – and a rationale for those payments – for two other provinces: Ontario and Newfoundland and Labrador. These increases would represent a net loss of tax dollars for respondents in Quebec. The control and treatment vignettes will differ in one respect. In the control group, the federal government makes the proposal. In the treatment, the independent council makes the proposal. We will administer the web-based survey on a sample of 1,000 residents who, if a provincial election were held on the day of the survey, would be eligible to vote. The survey will be conducted by Vox Pop Labs, which maintains a large panel of online respondents in Quebec.

q16.value: We want to examine whether a hypothetical council can convince voters to accept changes to Canada’s equalization system, even when those changes result in gains (losses) for other (their) province. Accordingly, we will randomly assign eligible Quebec voters to one of two groups: one in which a proposal to improve equalization for other provinces is proposed by the federal government and another in which it is proposed by a hypothetical independent council. The vignette appears below. The control and treatment vignettes are identical with the following exceptions: only the treatment group will see the text in bold and only the control group will see the text in square brackets. Vignette: Every year, the federal government makes equalization payments to provinces with below-average capacity to raise revenues. The purpose of these payments is to ensure that all Canadians enjoy comparable levels of public services at comparable levels of taxation. One criticism of the program is that payments only reflect the ability of provinces to raise revenues, not the different amounts provinces have to pay to provide similar public services. To address this problem, the newly created Canadian Equalization Commission [“the federal government”] recently developed a proposal to adjust equalization payments. The proposal, if implemented, would increase payments for Ontario and Newfoundland and Labrador, two provinces with exceptionally high service costs. It would have no effect on the remaining provinces. Manitoba, Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island would continue to receive the same amounts. British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan would continue to receive no payments. The Canadian Equalization Commission is an independent body designed to assess the fairness of Canada’s equalization system. It consists of 10 experts – one from each province – and operates independently of the federal and provincial governments. After exposing respondents to the vignette, we will ask them whether they support the proposal. The answers will serve as our dependent variable. We will randomize the order of response options. The question: Do you support the new proposal to adjust provinces’ equalization payments? • I strongly oppose the proposal • I somewhat oppose the proposal • I neither support nor oppose the proposal • I somewhat support the proposal • I strongly support the proposal If the council is persuasive, the treatment group will, on average, be more likely to say they support the proposal. The literature suggests reasons to be both optimistic and pessimistic about the council’s effect. Thus, we do not have any expectations about the size and direction of the overall effect. We do, however, expect effects to vary across different groups, which we discuss next. Heterogeneous treatment effects Federal partisan identification: We expect a proposal originating from the council to have the biggest positive effect on respondents who identify with the federal New Democratic Party. Left-right ideology: We expect the effect of a council relative to a government proposal to increase with leftist ideology. Views on state and individual responsibility: We expect the effect of a council relative to a government proposal to increase with favourable attitudes towards a state role in providing for Canadians. Identity: We expect individuals with strong Canadian identities to be more receptive to the council than the federal government. We don’t have any expectations for individuals who identify equally with Canada and their province. Political Knowledge: We expect high-knowledge individuals to be less affected by the council than low-knowledge individuals. General effects Federal partisanship: We expect support for the proposal to be highest, in general, among those who identify with the federal Liberal party. Left-right ideology: We expect support for the proposal to increase with leftist ideology. Views on government and individual responsibility: We expect support for the proposal to increase with favourable attitudes towards a state role in providing for Canadians. Identity: We expect individuals with strong Canadian identities to be more likely to support the proposal. We expect individuals with strong provincial identities to be less likely to support the proposal. Employment status: We expect individuals to be less supportive of the proposal if they or a member of their household has been unemployed at any point within the last 12 months. Measures of our variables can be found in the French and English surveys in appendices 1 and 2.

q17.value: Because our data are experimental, we will analyze them with simple bivariate tests, though we will also employ multiple regression analysis to ensure our results are not driven by random imbalance across treatment groups.

attributes.title: Gender Bias in Retrospective Performance Evaluations

q1.value: Gender Bias in Retrospective Performance Evaluations

q2.value: Roosmarijn De Geus | John McAndrews | Peter Loewen

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The aim of the study is to test whether there is gender bias in the retrospective evaluation of performance of male and female political executives.

q16.value: Our main hypothesis is that female executives will receive lower levels of credit and blame compared to male executives due to gender biases in the perception of female and male leaders. We expect several factors to moderate this relationship, such as the policy domain, the leadership style and partisanship. We furthermore hypothesise about the effect of positive performance and leadership style on the description (traits) of leaders, where we expect that positive levels of performance increase the likelihood that female executives are described using masculine terms; and that an independent leadership style will reduce the likelihood that female executives are described using feminine terms.

q17.value: We use a conjoint set up and estimate Average Marginal Component Effects as well as Average Component Interaction Effects using OLS regression models.

registration_responses.q1: Gender Bias in Retrospective Performance Evaluations
registration_responses.q2: Roosmarijn De Geus | John McAndrews | Peter Loewen

attributes.title: From Sanction to Supervision: Evaluating the Impact of Court-Ordered Desegregation Plans on Racial Attitudes in the U.S. South

q1.value: From Sanction to Supervision: Evaluating the Impact of Court-Ordered Desegregation Plans on Racial Attitudes in the U.S. South

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Understanding the historical impact of school integration on racial attitudes in the United States has important implications for the present day: Racial prejudice remains a source of discrimination and social strife, and despite the dramatic racial integration of public schools in the 1960s and 1970s, schools nationwide have significantly re-segregated since the high-water mark of this integration effort. My project will investigate whether the duration of federally enforced desegregation of school districts in the U.S. South following the Brown and Brown II decisions exerted a lasting, independent effect on the racial attitudes and partisanship of white residents in those districts. This project will contribute to literatures on race-conscious policymaking and the formation of racial attitudes.

q16.value: This project will produce analysis that will adjudicate between conflicting hypotheses in the literature on interracial contact. Increased contact as the result of sustained federal intervention may improve racial attitudes by facilitating interracial personal relationships. Conversely, administrative burden of federally enforced integration coupled with a perceived sense of racial threat may cool attitudes. Third, racial attitudes may be entrenched through social processes the effects of which institutional interventions cannot effectively attenuate. The quantities of interest to assess these competing hypotheses are the associations between the duration of court-monitored desegregation plan implementation and CCES measures of partisan identification and racial resentment.

q17.value: Exploiting the quasi-randomness of the timing and duration of court-monitored desegregation plan implementation, I will use OLS regression to determine the relationship between plan duration and outcomes related to racial attitudes. I will also condition on the group that initiated court proceedings and plan intensiveness to explore the effects of different types of intervention.

registration_responses.q1: From Sanction to Supervision: Evaluating the Impact of Court-Ordered Desegregation Plans on Racial Attitudes in the U.S. South

attributes.title: The IMF Betrayed the People! A Survey Experiment on Populism and Blame Attribution

q1.value: The IMF Betrayed the People! A Survey Experiment on Populism and Blame Attribution

q2.value: Ayse Kaya | Sam Handlin | Hakan Gunaydin

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The 21st century has witnessed a remarkable rise of populist politics and mobilization. As a style of politics that emphasizes the sovereignty of “the people” and demonizes financial and political elites, populist rhetoric is inherently hostile toward powerful international organizations (IOs) like the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Indeed, prominent populist leaders frequently rail against international organizations and the rise of populist movements is often seen as posing a challenge to the liberal international order. While these aspects of populism are broadly theorized, we know relatively little about whether the rising tide of populism has actually turned mass publics against IOs like the IMF. One initial question is whether populist voters are more likely than others to blame institutions like the IMF for their country’s economic difficulties. Our extant research utilizing observational data from the European Social Survey demonstrates the existence of a robust association between support for populist parties and a tendency to blame the IMF for economic trouble (in countries where the IMF has offered structural adjustment programs). We now plan to probe further the nature of this relationship between populist preferences and the tendency to place blame on the IMF. What mechanisms explain the association between these behaviors? The hostility of populist politicians toward the IMF might convince the masses to place more blame on the IMF, a scapegoating mechanism. Alternatively, the association between populist voting preferences and anti-IMF attitudes might be explained by populist politicians simply capitalizing on the electorate’s already extant anti-IMF sentiment. This pre-analysis plan describes an online survey experiment that will be fielded in Greece designed to help us better adjudicate between these mechanisms. Using different vignettes randomly assigned to respondents, we assess whether scapegoating cues – one that is anti-IMF but not populist and one that is overtly populist – increase the relative blame individuals place on the IMF for Greece’s economic difficulties and whether these messages have heterogeneous effects across populist and non-populist individuals.

q16.value: Our main theoretical concern is to assess the micro-level evidence for the scapegoating mechanism that might explain the individual-level association between populist beliefs and anti-IMF attitudes. The scapegoating theory suggests that voters acquire anti-IMF attitudes not just by exposure to the IMF’s activities but via cues from politicians seeking to lay the blame on the IMF. If we find support for H1, we have evidence for the scapegoating mechanism. If we do not find support for H1, this would undermine the case for scapegoating and be consistent with the capitalizing mechanism. H1: Respondents exposed to Vignette 2 and Vignette 3 will place more relative blame on the IMF than respondents exposed to Vignette 1. We also would like to evaluate whether scapegoating using explicitly populist language is more effective in this regard than scapegoating without such rhetoric. H2: Respondents exposed to Vignette 3 will place more relative blame on the IMF than respondents exposed to Vignette 2. Subgroup Analysis The scapegoating mechanism also suggests heterogeneous effects across respondents with more populist and less populist belief systems. If scapegoating holds, we expect that cues from politicians attacking the IMF will have a particularly strong impact on individuals who already hold populist worldviews. H3: Populist respondents exposed to Vignette 2 and Vignette 3 will place more relative blame on the IMF than non-populist individuals exposed to Vignette 2 and Vignette 3.

registration_responses.q1: The IMF Betrayed the People! A Survey Experiment on Populism and Blame Attribution
registration_responses.q2: Ayse Kaya | Sam Handlin | Hakan Gunaydin
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q2.value: Jennifer Pan | Daniel Muise | Byron Reeves

q5.value: We thank the Knight Foundation for financial support, and members of the Screenomics Lab for support and suggestions

registration_responses.q2: Jennifer Pan | Daniel Muise | Byron Reeves
registration_responses.q5: We thank the Knight Foundation for financial support, and members of the Screenomics Lab for support and suggestions
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

q2.value: Christian Breunig | Klaus Jonathan Klüser | Qixuan Yang

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This experiment seeks to research the effect of regular “nudges” on students’ learningoutcomes. Drawing on insights from behavioral economics, research on higher educationhas shown that regular and unobtrusive nudges can shape students’ behavior (Thaler & Sunstein, 2009). While nudges can take numerous forms, textual nudges are most effec-tively delivered via text messages (Patrick et al., 2009). As one example of the impactof textual nudges in a university context, Castleman & Page (2015) demonstrate howpersonalized text messages can help to induce students to sign up for university courseson time. Besides the medium of communication, the impact of textual nudges criticallyhinges on their wording. While principally a nudge can operate via six different psy-chological mechanisms, the appeal to resource scarcity like time stands out in terms ofeffectiveness Cialdini (2001). Following this line, our experiment tests whether studentswho receive a weekly, personalized text message reminding them about the next upcom-ing lecture session and the assigned literature achieve a better learning outcome.

q16.value: Students obtain better learning outcomes, when they receive regular re-minders about reading the assigned weekly literature.

registration_responses.q2: Christian Breunig | Klaus Jonathan Klüser | Qixuan Yang

attributes.title: The Sources of Citizen-Police Cooperation: Experimental Evidence Using 360-degree Video in Lagos, Nigeria

q1.value: The Sources of Citizen-Police Cooperation: Experimental Evidence Using 360-degree Video in Lagos, Nigeria

q9.value: The pre-analysis plan was submitted prior to treatment assignment on March 6, 2018 via email due to technical difficulties with the EGAP site. The registration info for the EGAP site (B3-10 & C4-13) was resubmitted on June 8, after researcher analysis.

q15.value: A Lagosian barkeeper, who regularly has his shop looted by “area boys” (local gangs), faces a dilemma. The boys abscond with his bottles to fasten into crude shanks and projectiles for bloody street fights. Does he report it to the police and, in his mind, risk retaliation? Or, does he remain silent as the boys demand? Citizens in gang-contested communities from Lagos to Sao Paolo to Baltimore often face some variant of this dilemma, and many choose what they perceive to be the safer choice: silence. The aggregate of these individual decisions creates an equilibrium at the local level that gives gangs the space to engage in illicit activity and violence with little concern for consequences from the state. This ability of gangs to block citizen cooperation ultimately undermines the state’s own authority in these communities. This experiment aims to contribute to the understanding of citizen decisions either to cooperate with the police or refrain from doing so.

q16.value: The experiment focuses on testing the effect of three cooperation inhibitors. One inhibitor is fear of retaliation from the gangs, or in some cases, from police. Given this fear, cooperation preferences and behavior remain private, so citizens lack “social proof” that others in their community are willing to come forward. Messaging that introduces an anonymous information provision platform combined with messaging on the willingness of others to use it may increase citizen information provision. Expected Outcome (Anonymity/Social Proof): Citizens exposed to messaging about an anonymous information provision platform used by others in their community are more likely to provide information about gang activity relative to those that remain unaware of the platform’s anonymity and adoption. A second theorized inhibitor is that police misconduct breeds resentment and inhibits cooperation. Contrary to this view, however, citizens prize security over suspect treatment. Thus, they likely do not incorporate suspect mistreatment into their cooperation decisions and may even increase information provision when exposed to misconduct. Expected Outcome (Suspect Mistreatment): Citizens exposed to police mistreatment of suspects are no less likely, or perhaps more likely, to provide information to the police. A third potential inhibitor are police forces that do not reflect the demographic make-up of communities and these differing demographic characteristics make citizens less apt to cooperate. Accordingly, co-ethnicity between a citizen and police officer may increase the citizen’s propensity to cooperate, especially from historically marginalized groups (e.g., Igbo in the context of Nigeria). Expected Outcome (Citizen-Police Co-ethnicity): Citizens are more likely to provide information to the police when exposed to police officers from a similar ethnic background.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested through a survey of shopkeepers in Lagos, Nigeria. The sampling frame includes shops in five market areas that have a strong area boy presence: Agege, Bariga, Ebute-Ero, Mushin, and Oshodi. The frame was created through conducting a census of all shops in each market area in November and December 2017. A random sample of 1,000 shops has been selected for surveying their owners. A second round of sampling will take place for surveying owners that share the shops with the first-round respondents. The researcher will manage the enumerators in the field as part of the Eko Community Survey (ECS), a collaborative project with two other researchers from U.S.-based universities.   Embedded in the survey are 360-degree videos produced by a Lagos-based production firm. Respondents are asked to imagine themselves in the role of a shopkeeper and watch the point-of-view vignette. In the vignette, respondents listen to a radio program introducing a text messaging line for sending information about fighting in their market, witness a non-graphic street fight with a police intervention, and are visited by an iyaloja (“market mother”). The videos vary in three ways that map on to the theorized cooperation inhibitors. Variation 1 is a factorial design varying the interaction between messaging that the platform is anonymous and used by others in the market. Variation 2 varies whether or not the police treat a suspect roughly during their intervention. Variation 3 varies the ethnicity of one of the intervening police officers indicated by an ethnic-sounding name. Each combination of the variations, totaling sixteen, is to be tested.     Variation 1 (Anonymity & Social Proof) Variation 2 (Suspect Treatment) Variation 3 (Police Ethnicity) 1 Anonymity Non-roughly Yoruba 2 Anonymity Roughly Yoruba 3 Anonymity Non-roughly Igbo 4 Anonymity Roughly Igbo 5 Social Proof Non-roughly Yoruba 6 Social Proof Roughly Yoruba 7 Social Proof Non-roughly Igbo 8 Social Proof Roughly Igbo 9 Anon. * Social Proof Non-roughly Yoruba 10 Anon. * Social Proof Roughly Yoruba 11 Anon. * Social Proof Non-roughly Igbo 12 Anon. * Social Proof Roughly Igbo 13 Placebo Non-roughly Yoruba 14 Placebo Roughly Yoruba 15 Placebo Non-roughly Igbo 16 Placebo Roughly Igbo   After viewing the video through Google Cardboard, the respondent indicates their likelihood of using the text messaging platform with a 4-point Likert scale of how much information, if any, they would send upon witnessing the fight depicted in the video. The analysis will be done using OLS with robust standard errors. Control variables include gender, age, education, income, religion, and ethnicity, along with market fixed effects.

registration_responses.q1: The Sources of Citizen-Police Cooperation: Experimental Evidence Using 360-degree Video in Lagos, Nigeria
registration_responses.q9: The pre-analysis plan was submitted prior to treatment assignment on March 6, 2018 via email due to technical difficulties with the EGAP site. The registration info for the EGAP site (B3-10 & C4-13) was resubmitted on June 8, after researcher analysis.

The boys abscond with his bottles to fasten into crude shanks and projectiles for bloody street fights. Does he report it to the police and, in his mind, risk retaliation? Or, does he remain silent as the boys demand? Citizens in gang-contested communities from Lagos to Sao Paolo to Baltimore often face some variant of this dilemma, and many choose what they perceive to be the safer choice: silence. The aggregate of these individual decisions creates an equilibrium at the local level that gives gangs the space to engage in illicit activity and violence with little concern for consequences from the state. This ability of gangs to block citizen cooperation ultimately undermines the state’s own authority in these communities. This experiment aims to contribute to the understanding of citizen decisions either to cooperate with the police or refrain from doing so.
registration_responses.q16: The experiment focuses on testing the effect of three cooperation inhibitors. One inhibitor is fear of retaliation from the gangs, or in some cases, from police. Given this fear, cooperation preferences and behavior remain private, so citizens lack “social proof” that others in their community are willing to come forward. Messaging that introduces an anonymous information provision platform combined with messaging on the willingness of others to use it may increase citizen information provision. Expected Outcome (Anonymity/Social Proof): Citizens exposed to messaging about an anonymous information provision platform used by others in their community are more likely to provide information about gang activity relative to those that remain unaware of the platform’s anonymity and adoption. A second theorized inhibitor is that police misconduct breeds resentment and inhibits cooperation. Contrary to this view, however, citizens prize security over suspect treatment. Thus, they likely do not incorporate suspect mistreatment into their cooperation decisions and may even increase information provision when exposed to misconduct. Expected Outcome (Suspect Mistreatment): Citizens exposed to police mistreatment of suspects are no less likely, or perhaps more likely, to provide information to the police. A third potential inhibitor are police forces that do not reflect the demographic make-up of communities and these differing demographic characteristics make citizens less apt to cooperate. Accordingly, co-ethnicity between a citizen and police officer may increase the citizen’s propensity to cooperate, especially from historically marginalized groups (e.g., Igbo in the context of Nigeria). Expected Outcome (Citizen-Police Co-ethnicity): Citizens are more likely to provide information to the police when exposed to police officers from a similar ethnic background.
registration_responses.q17: The hypotheses will be tested through a survey of shopkeepers in Lagos, Nigeria. The sampling frame includes shops in five market areas that have a strong area boy presence: Agege, Bariga, Ebute-Ero, Mushin, and Oshodi. The frame was created through conducting a census of all shops in each market area in November and December 2017. A random sample of 1,000 shops has been selected for surveying their owners. A second round of sampling will take place for surveying owners that share the shops with the first-round respondents. The researcher will manage the enumerators in the field as part of the Eko Community Survey (ECS), a collaborative project with two other researchers from U.S.-based universities.   Embedded in the survey are 360-degree videos produced by a Lagos-based production firm. Respondents are asked to imagine themselves in the role of a shopkeeper and watch the point-of-view vignette. In the vignette, respondents listen to a radio program introducing a text messaging line for sending information about fighting in their market, witness a non-graphic street fight with a police intervention, and are visited by an iyaloja (“market mother”). The videos vary in three ways that map on to the theorized cooperation inhibitors. Variation 1 is a factorial design varying the interaction between messaging that the platform is anonymous and used by others in the market. Variation 2 varies whether or not the police treat a suspect roughly during their intervention. Variation 3 varies the ethnicity of one of the intervening police officers indicated by an ethnic-sounding name. Each combination of the variations, totaling sixteen, is to be tested.     Variation 1 (Anonymity & Social Proof) Variation 2 (Suspect Treatment) Variation 3 (Police Ethnicity) 1 Anonymity Non-roughly Yoruba 2 Anonymity Roughly Yoruba 3 Anonymity Non-roughly Igbo 4 Anonymity Roughly Igbo 5 Social Proof Non-roughly Yoruba 6 Social Proof Roughly Yoruba 7 Social Proof Non-roughly Igbo 8 Social Proof Roughly Igbo 9 Anon. * Social Proof Non-roughly Yoruba 10 Anon. * Social Proof Roughly Yoruba 11 Anon. * Social Proof Non-roughly Igbo 12 Anon. * Social Proof Roughly Igbo 13 Placebo Non-roughly Yoruba 14 Placebo Roughly Yoruba 15 Placebo Non-roughly Igbo 16 Placebo Roughly Igbo   After viewing the video through Google Cardboard, the respondent indicates their likelihood of using the text messaging platform with a 4-point Likert scale of how much information, if any, they would send upon witnessing the fight depicted in the video. The analysis will be done using OLS with robust standard errors. Control variables include gender, age, education, income, religion, and ethnicity, along with market fixed effects.

q2.value: Pearce Edwards | Michael Hanley | Handi Li

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We examine whether partisan misinformation is more likely to be believed than nonpartisan misinformation through a survey experiment on Amazon Mechanical Turk. We also provide descriptive evidence on whether one's level of affective polarization in politics affects their propensity to believe misinformation, as well as whether Republicans or Democrats are more susceptible to misinformation. With this survey, we plan to contribute to multiple literatures. We will contribute to the study of affective polarization - a growing and important aspect of American political behavior, and the study of political misinformation.

q16.value: H1: Respondents are more susceptible to partisan fake news than to non-partisan fake news. H2: High-level aective polarization between parties increases susceptibility to fake news. H3: Democrats are less susceptible to (partisan) fake news than Republicans.

q17.value: Hypothesis 1 will be tested through a difference-in-means estimator and regression analysis. Hypothesis 2 will be tested through conditional average treatment effects and a regression analysis. Hypothesis 3 will take the same approach as Hypothesis 2.

q23.value: Under review (study conducted after IRB approval received)

attributes.title: When do most voters support increasing immigration? Disentangling (parochial) altruistic motivations from self-interest and prejudice

q1.value: When do most voters support increasing immigration? Disentangling (parochial) altruistic motivations from self-interest and prejudice

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Widespread opposition to immigration among even educated and racially egalitarian voters is hard to explain using existing frameworks that attribute these sentiments to self-interest or prejudice. To address this puzzle, I develop a theory of parochial altruism stipulating that voters are often willing to help others at a personal cost, but they want to help their compatriots first. Accordingly, conditional on at least weak bias toward their compatriots, altruistic voters should be expected to oppose globally efficient policies that pose a conflict between greater national and global good. Given widespread perceptions about immigration's negative national impacts, the theory implies that voters tend to favor harsh restrictions on immigration when they perceive such restrictions as necessary to secure the well-being of their compatriots. To test the parochial altruism hypothesis against existing theories, I then aim to conduct a population-based conjoint survey experiment in the UK and other advanced democracies. In doing so, I estimate the effect of perceived national interest--as opposed to self-interest and other competing concerns--on policy choice with regard to immigration. The proposed survey experiment is part of a larger population-based UK study related to the project on parochial altruism and migration.

q16.value: H1 (Altruism): Independent of personal consequences, the more positive (negative) beliefs about policy's social impacts, the more supportive (opposed) voters are of a policy. H2 (Parochial altruism): Independent of personal consequences, the beliefs about policy's group impacts are more important than global impacts for policy support. H3 (National parochial altruism): Independent of personal and global consequences, the beliefs about policy's national impacts are more important than other group impacts for policy support. H4A (Pure self-interest): Independent of personal consequences, beliefs about policy's social impacts are not related to how much supportive (opposed) voters are of a policy. H5A (Unconditional values / ethnic prejudice): Independent of any consequences, the lower (greater) the number or ethnic difference of immigration, the more supportive (opposed) voters are of a policy. H6H (Revealed altruism or egoism) The effect difference of social versus personal policy consequences is greater among revealed altruists (compared to revealed egoists).

q17.value: To test my argument, I propose to explicitly manipulate the beliefs about policy effects on one's interests using a conjoint experiment in which respondents choose between alternative policy pairs with specified tradeoffs. Put differently, I aim to estimate the elasticity of immigration preferences to various personal and social interest effect perceptions. In doing so, I employ an established multidimensional choice experiment technique (Hainmueller, Hopkins, & Yamamoto, 2014). Specifically, I ask respondents to choose from a sufficient number (5) of hypothetical policy vignette pairs that would have heterogeneous implications for the number of immigrants from different regions, as well as one's (economic) self-, local, national, and human interest of various magnitude. For instance, would people be more supportive of an immigration policy if, as explicitly stated, it marginally increased their own economic well-being as opposed to a similar proposal that might also substantially undermine national economy? While the first (main) outcome question optimally forces respondents to choose one of the policies, the second (auxiliary) question asks respondents to rate each policy on a 7-point scale. Given that all the policy consequences are randomized simultaneously and their effects are measured on the same scale, such design allows examining the relative importance of various (potentially correlated) motivations that underlie immigration preferences. Since the data is on the individual level, it is also possible to assess whether various subgroups of voters respond differently to specific policy consequences or combinations thereof. In testing my hypotheses, I will follow the empirical approach developed by Hainmueller (2014) and estimate average marginal component effects (AMCEs) using simple linear regression with robust standard errors clustered by respondent. The AMCE represents the average difference in the probability of being chosen when comparing two different attribute values (e.g., a policy proposal of immigration from Western Europe versus Eastern Europe) where the average is taken over all possible other attribute combinations.
